body:
Your terminal emulator might actually be telling Alacritty to invert the colors. Judging by the black/white mix, I'd assume that's exactly how that is achieved.

Now if emojis should be affected by that is a different question, but that's likely what's going on. So if you would set the manual color codes instead of using the inversion escape, that should resolve the problem.

That seems plausible, but this doesn't happen in Terminal or iTerm 2.

On 12/05, Christian Duerr wrote:
>Your terminal emulator might actually be telling Alacritty to invert the colors. Judging by the black/white mix, I'd assume that's exactly how that is achieved.
>
>Now if emojis should be affected by that is a different question, but that's likely what's going on. So if you would set the manual color codes instead of using the inversion escape, that should resolve the problem.
>
>-- 
>You are receiving this because you authored the thread.
>Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub:
>https://github.com/jwilm/alacritty/issues/1864#issuecomment-444692351

It's hard for me to test this since I do not have any colored emojis installed, but it should be pretty simple to try and reproduce that behavior.

Try running this escape sequence in bash:
`echo -e "\e[7mINVERTED: \U1F600\e[0mNORMAL: \U1F600"`

This should print one inverted emoji and one normal one. In theory both should look the same in iTerm/Terminal.app but look different in Alacritty.

Note that I don't think this works in the version of bash which is installed on macOS by default, so you might need to replace the unicode escapes with emojis yourself or update bash.
Thanks so much @chrisduerr. Your test worked perfectly. Your hunch was right. Terminal.app Alacritty Still no idea how to fix.

It should be possible to work around this by changing the formatting of the tmux statusline.

A more proper solution would be to prevent emojis from getting inverted though.

rename.from: Emoji color inverts when window gets activity
rename.to: Ignore emojis when inverting cells on macOS

body:
I'm not sure what you mean by "changing the formatting"?  It's the name of the window.  How do I tell tmux to render them not inverse?

On 12/09, Christian Duerr wrote:
>It should be possible to work around this by changing the formatting of the tmux statusline.
>
>A more proper solution would be to prevent emojis from getting inverted though.
>
>-- 
>You are receiving this because you authored the thread.
>Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub:
>https://github.com/jwilm/alacritty/issues/1864#issuecomment-445551838

@chrisduerr update: I noticed that this affects everything. Not just tmux. You probably already inferred that but I just wanted to make sure it was documented that emoji always invert their colors when highlighted.

rename.from: Ignore emojis when inverting cells on macOS
rename.to: Always render emojis with default color

body: Changed the title to include the following issue: https://github.com/jwilm/alacritty/issues/2160

issue.title: Emoji color display is not normal
issue.body:
Which operating system does the issue occur on?
macos
If on linux, are you using X11 or Wayland?


Emoji color display is not normal like this pic，how to set this？
![qq20190307-122717](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/41671631/53932392-5b44f100-40d4-11e9-851d-bd51f540a321.png)

body:
@chrisduerr I'd like to give this issue a try!
Could you point me in the right direction? I wonder how to test that that emojis themselves are unaffected by inversion...

Cells are inversed [here](https://github.com/jwilm/alacritty/blob/master/src/term/mod.rs#L286-L292) so any fix would likely be placed there too.

The tougher task would be figuring out what's an emoji and what isn't. I don't know if there's any official way to detect this and there might be, but if there's not we'd likely have to resort to matching the char value against a list of unicode characters to include (like everything in the range of 1F600—1F64F).

@chrisduerr I can't reach that file unfortunately. Is there any `mod.rs` in the project at all?
I would like to give this issue a try too.

Looks like the file has moved and I haven't linked to a fixed commit. This should be the correct path:
https://github.com/jwilm/alacritty/tree/34c54e7e0eb7c28406df112d118b82280be2adee/alacritty_terminal/src/term/mod.rs#L285-L294

@felipesere do you see a more appropriate solution? I think it is really possible to check `cell.c` against a list of emoji range in unicode but this way Alacritty would support emojis only manually, hence when new emojis appear, they will be inverted and should be manually added to the range.
